content.description:
This is an old moderate problem which has eroded into a more challenging roof move.

Ascend a slab to the middle of the lower roof. Fight through this problem with a variety of mantle, heel hook, and funky friction. Apparently, a hold broke off in the last decade and made it a tricky problem. It is particularly challenging for short kids.

For a moderate variation (~5.7), you can skirt the first roof on the left, then ascend easier terrain above to the anchor.
content.protection: Use long slings to anchor off the pole up top. Once, there was a chockstone up top to use, but now it seems like the pole is all that remains. There is a pocket that may catch your eye just below the top, but a sideways force yanks it right out.
content.location: Climb up the middle of the south face.

content.description: A series of several fun boulder problems stacked on top of each other.  Overhung jamming and stemming off the ground followed by a series of mantles and slabby face moves.  Pumpy finish out of a little alcove.
content.protection: TR from the metal pole on the summit with long slings (15ft).  Could be led with gear.  A bolt protects the last move.
content.location: South face of Castle Rock proper.  Just to the right of the Waimea Wall boulder problem.

content.description:
This is the face route that is just to the left of the chimney route.  Over the years, this route's features have gotten smoother with erosion.

You can start as for the chimney and move onto the face.  You could also start with a much harder start from the left over a bulge.  Carefully smear your way up.  The top out move felt like the crux.

It may be tougher for small kids. It is also used for guiding.
content.protection: To toprope, you need lengthy slings to extend from the pipe up top.
content.location: On the right side of the south face.

content.description:
Chock stone is found left of the 5.5 summit route and right of the huge cave. look for the obvious dihedral that is only about 30 feet high.

This climb is short but fun and good to do if your arms are tired as it can be stemmed almost the whole way up. Pass a 5.8 bulge / roof for the crux to easier ground above.

One and a half stars.
content.protection: You can set a TR anchor by going up the summit route and slinging a natural hole in the rock equalized with a solid single bolt.

content.description:
This is a chimney climb located on the right side of the south face of Castle Rock.  It can be top-roped (or lead).

The crux may be near the start where you fight some awkward moves to get established in the chimney.

It may be tougher for small kids.  It is also used for guiding.
content.protection: Cams.  A very long set of slings if you top rope off the top.
content.location: On the right side of the south face.

content.description: Climb up into the cave right to farewell to arms. Then out the roof. Super fun.
content.location: Right of farewell to arms. Starts in the left side of the big cave.

content.description:
On the left side of the south face of Castle Rock is probably the easiest way to the top.  Once this may have been considered 5.0, but erosion has left this a bit trickier.

You can start up a crack on the left side with big stems

or

go around left and pass a bulge.  Pass another minor bulge with an awkward crack.  Thread a natural slot, and move left.  One small step and you're on top.

You can downclimb this or rappel off to the north.

It can get busy with clients or downclimbers.

You might consider this as you search for a first outdoor climb for your young, budding rock climbing nephrew, but it's a bit of a challenge for those younger than 8.  Maybe the

Swiss Cheese Face

on Goat Rock?
content.protection: A few cams to #1 Camalot, a bolt, a natural thread.
content.location: This is on the left side of the south face of Castle Rock.
